sen.j: 松平 定喬（まつだいら さだたか、正徳 (日本)6年6月9日 (旧暦)（1716年7月27日） - 宝暦13年3月21日 (旧暦)（1763年5月3日））は江戸時代の大名。
sen.e: Sadataka MATSUDAIRA (July 27, 1716-May 3, 1763) was daimyo who lived during the Edo period.
Sadataka MATSUDAIRA (July 27, 1716 - May 3, 1763) was a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) who lived during the Edo period.
Sadataka MATSUDAIRA (July 27, 1716 - May 3, 1763) was a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) who lived during the Edo period.

sen.j: 伊予松山藩6代藩主。
sen.e: He was the sixth feudal lord of the Iyo-Matsuyama domain.
He was the sixth feudal lord of the Iyo-Matsuyama clan.
He was the sixth feudal lord of the Iyo-Matsuyama clan.

sen.j: 定勝系久松松平家宗家7代。
sen.e: He was the seventh head of the Hisamatsu-Matsudaira family of the Sadakatsu lineage.
He was the seventh head of the Hisamatsu-Matsudaira family of the Sadakatsu lineage.
He was the seventh head of the Hisamatsu-Matsudaira family of the Sadakatsu lineage.

sen.j: 5代藩主松平定英の長男。
sen.e: He was the first son of Sadahide MATSUDAIRA, the fifth feudal lord.
He was the oldest son of Sadahide MATSUDAIRA, the fifth feudal lord.
He was the oldest son of Sadahide MATSUDAIRA, the fifth feudal lord.

sen.j: 母は島津綱貴の女（正室・信解院殿、2代藩主松平定頼の曾孫）。
sen.e: His mother was a daughter of Tsunataka SHIMAZU (whose lawful wife was Shingein and who was a grandson of Sadayori MATSUDAIRA, the second feudal lord).
His mother was a daughter of Tsunataka SHIMAZU (also known as Shingein, Sadahide's lawful wife and a granddaughter of Sadayori MATSUDAIRA, the second feudal lord).
sen.cmt: 「定英の正室」「曾孫（女）」として修正しました。
sen.e: His mother was a daughter of Tsunataka SHIMAZU (also known as Shingein, Sadahide's lawful wife and a granddaughter of Sadayori MATSUDAIRA, the second feudal lord).

sen.j: 正室は佐竹義峯の娘。
sen.e: His lawful wife was a daughter of Yoshimine SATAKE.
His lawful wife was a daughter of Yoshimine SATAKE.
His lawful wife was a daughter of Yoshimine SATAKE.

sen.j: 子に鉄（松平定国正室）。
sen.e: He had a child called Tetsu (who became the lawful wife of Sadakuni MATSUDAIRA).
He had a child called Tetsu (who became the lawful wife of Sadakuni MATSUDAIRA).
He had a child called Tetsu (who became the lawful wife of Sadakuni MATSUDAIRA).

sen.j: 幼名は百助。
sen.e: His childhood name was Momosuke.
His childhood name was Momosuke.
His childhood name was Momosuke.

sen.j: 官位官職は従四位下、隠岐守、侍従。
sen.e: His official rank and government post were Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade), Oki no kami (Governor of Oki Province), and chamberlain.
His official rank and government post were Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Oki no kami (Governor of Oki Province), and chamberlain.
His official rank and government post were Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Oki no kami (Governor of Oki Province), and chamberlain.

sen.j: 正徳6年（1716年）6月9日誕生。
sen.e: He was born on June 9, 1716.
He was born on July 27, 1716.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直しました。
sen.e: He was born on July 27, 1716.

sen.j: 享保15年（1730年）、従五位下山城守に叙任。
sen.e: In 1730, he was appointed to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), Yamashiro no kami (Governor of Yamashiro Province).
In 1730, he was appointed to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), Yamashiro no kami (Governor of Yamashiro Province).
In 1730, he was appointed to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), Yamashiro no kami (Governor of Yamashiro Province).

sen.j: その3年後、父・定英の卒去により遺領松山藩15万石を継承。
sen.e: Three years later, due to death of his father, Sadahide, he inherited the property of Matsuyama domain of 15,000-koku (a unit of volume).
Three years later, due to death of his father Sadahide, he inherited the property of Matsuyama domain of 15,000 koku crop yields.
Three years later, due to death of his father Sadahide, he inherited the property of Matsuyama domain of 15,000 koku crop yields.

sen.j: 2カ月後、隠岐守に転任。
sen.e: Two months later, he was reassigned to Oki no kami.
Two months later, he was transferred to Oki no kami.
Two months later, he was transferred to Oki no kami.

sen.j: 享保21年（1736年）、先祖陽光院殿（久松俊勝）の百五十回忌の為、三河国安楽寺で法要を営む。
sen.e: In 1736, for the 149th anniversary of death of his ancestor, Yokoin (Toshikatsu HISAMATSU), he performed a Buddhist memorial service at Anraku-ji Temple in Mikawa Province.
In 1736, for the 149th anniversary of death of his ancestor, Yokoin (Toshikatsu HISAMATSU), he performed a Buddhist memorial service at Anraku-ji Temple in Mikawa Province.
sen.cmt: 半角スペースにしました。
sen.e: In 1736, for the 149th anniversary of death of his ancestor, Yokoin (Toshikatsu HISAMATSU), he performed a Buddhist memorial service at Anraku-ji Temple in Mikawa Province.

sen.j: 元文元年（1736年）、従四位下に昇る。
sen.e: In 1736, he was promoted to Jushiinoge.
In 1736, he was promoted to Jushiinoge.
In 1736, he was promoted to Jushiinoge.

sen.j: 延享4年（1747年）、桃園天皇立太子の賀詞のため、朝廷への御使に任ぜられ、侍従に叙任。
sen.e: In 1747, for gashi (congratulations) of investiture of the Crown Prince of Emperor Momozono, he was appointed as a messenger to the Imperial Court and was appointed to a chamberlain.
In 1747, for gashi (congratulations) of investiture of the Crown Prince of Emperor Momozono, he was appointed as a messenger to the Imperial Court and was appointed to a chamberlain.
In 1747, for gashi (congratulations) of investiture of the Crown Prince of Emperor Momozono, he was appointed as a messenger to the Imperial Court and was appointed to a chamberlain.

sen.j: 京都へ至り桜町天皇に拝謁。
sen.e: He went to Kyoto and was granted an audience with Emperor Sakuramachi.
He went to Kyoto and was granted an audience with Emperor Sakuramachi.
He went to Kyoto and was granted an audience with Emperor Sakuramachi.

sen.j: 宝暦6年（1756年）、初代松平定行以来100年間、途絶えていた伺候席に任ぜられる。
sen.e: In 1756, he was appointed to shikoseki (anteroom seats for feudal lords and direct retainer of the shogun at the Edo-jo castle) to which no one had been appointed for 100 years since the first-generation Sadayuki MATSUDAIRA.

In 1756, he was appointed to shikoseki (anteroom seats for feudal lords and direct retainer of the shogun at the Edo-jo castle) to which no one had been appointed for 100 years since the first-generation Sadayuki MATSUDAIRA.

In 1756, he was appointed to shikoseki (anteroom seats for feudal lords and direct retainer of the shogun at the Edo-jo castle) to which no one had been appointed for 100 years since the first-generation Sadayuki MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 宝暦13年（1763年）、病に陥りまもなく危篤に陥り、弟の松平定功（さだなり）を養嗣とする。
sen.e: In 1763, he fell ill and soon fell into a critical condition, and he adopted his younger brother Sadanari MATSUDAIRA as his heir.
In 1763, he fell ill and soon fell into a critical condition, and he adopted his younger brother Sadanari MATSUDAIRA as his heir.
In 1763, he fell ill and soon fell into a critical condition, and he adopted his younger brother Sadanari MATSUDAIRA as his heir.

sen.j: そして3月21日に江戸松山藩邸愛宕下上屋敷にて卒去。
sen.e: Then on May 3, he died at his Atagoshita kamiyashiki (daimyo's regular residence), Edo-Matsuyama domain's hantei (residence maintained by daimyo in Edo).
Then on May 3, he died at his Atagoshita kamiyashiki (daimyo's regular residence in Atagoshita), Edo-Matsuyama clan's hantei (residence maintained by daimyo in Edo).
Then on May 3, he died at his Atagoshita kamiyashiki (daimyo's regular residence in Atagoshita), Edo-Matsuyama clan's hantei (residence maintained by daimyo in Edo).

sen.j: 享年48。
sen.e: He died at the age of forty-eight.
Died at the age of 48.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: Died at the age of 48.

sen.j: 法号は顕徳院殿従四位拾遺補闕前隠州順誉和光慈観大居士。
sen.e: His hogo (a Buddhist name) was 顕徳院殿従四位拾遺補闕前隠州順誉和光慈観大居士.
His hogo (a Buddhist name) was 顕徳院殿従四位拾遺補闕前隠州順誉和光慈観大居士.
His hogo (a Buddhist name) was 顕徳院殿従四位拾遺補闕前隠州順誉和光慈観大居士.

sen.j: 遺骸は三田済海寺に土葬される。
sen.e: The body was buried at Saikai-ji Temple in Sanda.
The body was buried at Saikai-ji Temple in Mita.
The body was buried at Saikai-ji Temple in Mita.

sen.j: 遺髪が松山市大林寺へ送られ法要が営まれる。
sen.e: The hair was sent to Dairin-ji Temple in Matsuyama City, where a Buddhist memorial service was conducted.
The hair was sent to Dairin-ji Temple in Matsuyama City, where a Buddhist memorial service was conducted.
The hair was sent to Dairin-ji Temple in Matsuyama City, where a Buddhist memorial service was conducted.

sen.j: これ以後、藩主は三田済海寺に土葬され、松山大林寺へは遺髪が送られることとなった。
sen.e: Since then, feudal lords were buried at Saikai-ji Temple in Sanda and the hair sent to Dairin-ji Temple in Matsuyama.
Since then, feudal lords were buried at Saikai-ji Temple in Mita and their hair sent to Dairin-ji Temple in Matsuyama.
Since then, feudal lords were buried at Saikai-ji Temple in Mita and their hair sent to Dairin-ji Temple in Matsuyama.
